title.narrative: Second Environmental Management and Capacity Building Project

description.narrative: The objective of the Second Environmental Management Capacity Building Project (EMCBP II) for Uganda is to contribute to sustainable management of environmental and natural resources at the national, district, and community levels. The additional credit will finance an extension of EMCBP II until November 30, 2011, to scale up activities and enhance the positive impacts of the existing project. The proposed scaled up activities include: (i) expansion of municipal solid waste (MSW) composting in 8 Ugandan towns to permit them to participate in carbon trade and to address a pressing local environmental problem; (ii) expansion of tree planting on denuded national forest lands; (iii) enhancement of enforcement capacity within National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA) to address priority environmental issues; and (iv) investment in priority environmental regulations, monitoring equipment and training relating to the rapidly expanding petroleum and gas sector in Uganda.

comment.narrative: These guidelines were developed with support under EMCBP, also IDA-funded

PAD describes the following guidelines as planned to be developed by the project: guidelines for conservation of biologicaldiversity; management of forests; sustainable management of rangelands; dangerous materials and processes; management of hazardouswastes; chemicals and materials; and gathering processing and dissemination of environmental information.
Earlier reported guidelines appear to have been work in progress and not finalized
These regulations were developed with support under EMCBP, also IDA-funded

PAD describes the following regulations: easements; oil spills and spillers liability; management of toxic and hazardous chemicalsand materials; standards for sub-sonic vibrations; standards for minimization of radiation; environmental standards of noise,control of noxious smells, solid waste disposal, vibration and sonic pollution, water use and air quality; and audit regulations.

New regulations include: Environment (Audit) Regulations, 2006 - gazetted; National Environment (Public Smoking Control)Regulations, 2004 - gazetted; and National Environment (Noise Standards and Control) Regulations, 2003; National Environment(minimum standards for management of soil quality) regulations 2001. Only Noise Standards and Control Regulations and AuditRegulations were includedin the original planned list of project-supported regulations

title.narrative: Environmental monitoring database for oil and gas established

comment.narrative: Server and software in place but database not yet populated with data; housed at NEMA

title.narrative: Improved and functional municipal solid waste (composting) facilities established and equipped

comment.narrative: 9 functional / operating facilities in Mukono, Jinja, Mbale, Soroti, Lira, Kasese, Fort Portal, Kabale, and Mbarara. 3 facilitiesin Arua, Hoima and Masindi constructed / not yet functional

title.narrative: Hectares of tree plantations established and maintained at least one season after planting in Kasagala and North Rwenzori CFR

comment.narrative: The total of 2,477 ha includes 1,677 in North Rwenzori CFR and 800 ha in Kasagala CFR [Source: NFA project completionreport]Actual lower than target due to (i) lower planting area than planned - area planted in North Rwenzori CFR was found to besmaller than originally reported due to inaccurate measurement); (ii) low survival of plantings in Kasagala CFR - 2,000 ha wereplanted but only 800 ha confirmed as established; (iii) the fact that some planting (20 ha) took place in the last season beforeproject closing date - thus, not maintained for one season after planting, as per indicator and is not included in this total

This total includes: 869,489 persons that benefitted from improved solid waste management in target municipalities; 8,968 otherreported beneficiaries under NEMA-implemented activities; and 12,400 beneficiaries under NFA tree planting component[Source:project completion reports, NEMA submission Jan 2013]Direct project beneficiaries include: (i) population benefitting fromimproved solid waste management in select municipalities; (ii) number of persons trained at national, district and community levels(NEMA staff, NFA staff, Lead Agency staff, district staff, LGstaff, NGO members, compost plant operators, teachers, etc.); (iii)beneficiaries of community benefit plants and microprojects financed by project; (iv) number of seasonal workers hired for treeplantation establishmentand maintenance; and (v) number of beneficiaries covered by CFM agreements.

title.narrative: Number of people benefitting from improved waste management systems in selected municipalities

comment.narrative: [Source: NEMA submission January 2013 based on estimated total population of participating municipalities, reduced by the lessthanfull coverage of solid waste management systems and including: Kasese (53,000); Fort Portal (67,315 - 80% of 84,144); Kabale(30,000- 60% of 50,000), Mbarara (86,174 - 80% of 107,717); Lira (90,000 - 60% of 150,000); Soroti (68,000 - all served); Mbale(300,000 -includes daytime population); Jinja (100,000 - Bugembe TC 30,000+MC 70,000); Mukono (75,000 - Central Business District)

title.narrative: Key sector policies reviewed re their environmental impacts (KPI)

comment.narrative: National Development Plan 2010; Renewable Energy Policy 2007; Land Use Policy (draft); Oil and Gas Policy 2008; Population Policy2008; National Industrial Policy 2008; Poverty Eradication Action Plan 2004; and Prosperity for All (PFA) Program 2006.(Activitycompleted by 2008)

title.narrative: Budget line for environment evident in sectoral Budget Framework Papers

comment.narrative: Budget for Water and Environment sector[Source: NEMA, based on MOFPED data]Based on information from the Ministry of Finance,there was concerted effort to include environment in sectoral budgets in the early years of project implementation; as the effortstopped, sectors reportedly no longer show a budget line on environment in their sectors, and this activity is no longer monitored

title.narrative: Curricula with environmental content/education in primary institutions adopted

comment.narrative: 100% primary curriculum informed of environmental issues examinable by UNEB. 50% of primary teachers in 56 districts trained.
100% primary curriculum informed of environmental issues examinable by UNEB. 50% of primary teachers in 56 districtstrained.(Activity completed by 2008)

title.narrative: Curricula with environmental content/education in tertiary institutions adopted

comment.narrative: 13 tertiary institutions curricula completed (100%)
13 tertiary institutions curricula completed (100%)(Activity completed by 2008)

title.narrative: Priority environmental interventions in the Strategic Development Plan / District Development Plan (SDP/DDP) implemented in focal districts

comment.narrative: At least 5 projects from each of the 27 districts

168 projects [Source: NEMA submission, Nov 5, 2012]Activity completed by 2008Based on the MTR AM, it appears that increase inthe number of projects is possibly due to decrease in project grant size, thus allowing for a larger number of microprojects

title.narrative: Central Forest Reserve (CFR) boundaries permanently demarcated with concrete pillars: North Rwenzori CFR

comment.narrative: As per NFA reporting.

title.narrative: Central Forest Reserve (CFR) boundaries permanently demarcated with concrete pillars: Kasagala CFR

comment.narrative: Demarcation included external boundary, as well as boundary around the enclaves inside the CFRs.

title.narrative: EIA frameworks developed and completed: Sectoral EIA

comment.narrative: EIA framework guidelines for mining sector.Other sectoral frameworks (Agriculture, Fisheries, urban Planning and Infrastructure,and Telecommunications) earlier reported as drafted with project support but not available

title.narrative: EIA frameworks developed and completed: Strategic EIA

comment.narrative: Earlier reported as drafted with project support - copy not made available
Indicator measured for focal districts only (previously reported on non-focal districts as well)[Source: NEMA, December2012](Activity completed by 2008)

title.narrative: Efficient charcoal kiln built and piloted

comment.narrative: Kilns established and tested in 2012; piloting ongoing - economic viability and sustainability after piloting stage unclear

title.narrative: The Authority (NEMA) own revenues as propotion of recurrent costs

comment.narrative: Own revenue is defined as GOU funding and National Environment FundApproved NEMA budget for 2012-2013 is fully funded by GoU[Source: Ministerial Policy Statement 2012-2013]

title.narrative: Curricula with environmental content/education in secondary institutions adopted

comment.narrative: Secondary school curriculum review completed - 2,400 institutions (secondary education)
Secondary school curriculum review completed - 2,400 institutions (secondary education)(Activity completed by 2008)

title.narrative: Hectares under Collaborative Forest Management (CFM) planted

comment.narrative: The total area planted includes 96 ha in North Rwenzori CFR and 35 ha in Kasagala CFR

title.narrative: Environmental issues mainstreamed into lead agency operations

comment.narrative: This number is reported by NEMA; however, substantiation of this is not available
in july-november 2011
in july-november 20117,952 cumulative for project durationProject funding for this activity ended in November 2011
Number reported by NEMA; actual roster not available. Gazettment reported not renewed in 2012

title.narrative: Environmental priorities (incl. protection, utilization & rehabilitation activities) are reflected in District Development Plan (KPI)

comment.narrative: Districts have fully integrated environmental activities in their planning. Non-focus districts have also begunintegrating.[Source: NEMA submission December 2012]

title.narrative: Training strategies (environmental awareness and education) implemented: Non-formal education

target.value: All 56 districts supported to conduct public awareness programs. Selected NGOs in each of the 56 districts trained on priorityenvironmental isues.Non-formal environment education conducted for community mobilizers in all 56 districts.

actual.value: All 56 districts supported to conduct public awareness programs. Selected NGOs in each of the 56 districts trained on priorityenvironmental isues.Non-formal environment education conducted for community mobilizers in all 56 districts.(Activity completedby 2008)

comment.narrative: Activity completed by 2008

comment.narrative: Activity completed by 2008

title.narrative: Compost produced from municipal solid waste (annually)

comment.narrative: Estimates only. Mukono - 1,492.9 tpy; Jinja - 1,990.6; Mbale - 2,213.6; Soroti - 1,235.5; Lira - 840.8; Fort Portall - 1,390;Kasese - 1,046.8; Mbarara - 1,372.8; Kabale - 1,698.8[Source: NEMA, Dec 11, 2012]
